summary: Manuel Ray was a prominent figure in Cuban politics, initially involved in the Cuban Revolution and later becoming a leader within the anti-Castro exile community. He is mentioned in documents spanning from 1958 to 1977. In the late 1950s, he was involved in rebel activities and reportedly had a planned meeting with Fidel Castro. By the early 1960s, Ray emerged as a key figure among Cuban exiles, with some reports suggesting he replaced Miro Cardona as the leader of the exiles with the backing of the United States. This alleged replacement caused controversy within the Cuban community. Documents also mention his potential involvement or association with various exile groups and activities aimed at undermining the Castro regime. The documents suggest a shift from revolutionary to exile leader, navigating the complex landscape of anti-Castro efforts.
significance: Manuel Ray's significance in the JFK context primarily stems from his role as a leader within the Cuban exile community. The documents suggest that he was considered a potential leader of the Cuban exiles, possibly with U.S. support. His position and activities within the exile community are relevant to understanding the broader context of anti-Castro efforts and U.S. involvement in Cuba during the period leading up to and following the JFK assassination. The documents do not directly link him to the JFK assassination, but his role in the exile community places him within the sphere of individuals and groups potentially involved in related activities.
